<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 276, 178, 292]]<|/det|>
## PHYSICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[832, 277, 905, 292]]<|/det|>
9702/51  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 300, 411, 316]]<|/det|>
Paper 5 Planning, Analysis and Evaluation  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[707, 301, 905, 316]]<|/det|>
October/November 2023  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[755, 325, 905, 340]]<|/det|>
1 hour 15 minutes

No additional materials are needed.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 418, 230, 433]]<|/det|>
## INSTRUCTIONS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 435, 808, 558]]<|/det|>
INSTRUCTIONS- Answer all questions.- Use a black or dark blue pen. You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.- Write your name, centre number and candidate number in the boxes at the top of the page.- Write your answer to each question in the space provided.- Do not use an erasable pen or correction fluid.- Do not write on any bar codes.- You may use a calculator.- You should show all your working and use appropriate units.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 588, 220, 602]]<|/det|>
## INFORMATION  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 604, 728, 635]]<|/det|>
INFORMATION- The total mark for this paper is 30.- The number of marks for each question or part question is shown in brackets [ ].

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 94, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 818, 91]]<|/det|>
Two coils, C and D, are placed with their axes on a straight line, as shown in Fig. 1.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[222, 98, 774, 223]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 243, 532, 262]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 1.1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 274, 604, 293]]<|/det|>
A resistor of resistance \(R\) is connected in series with coil C.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 305, 918, 339]]<|/det|>
A changing magnetic flux of frequency \(f\) in coil C causes an electromotive force (e.m.f.) \(E\) to be induced across the terminals of coil D.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 352, 562, 371]]<|/det|>
It is suggested that \(E\) is related to \(f\) by the relationship

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[460, 375, 541, 405]]<|/det|>
\[E = \frac{of^qV}{R}\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 413, 873, 432]]<|/det|>
where \(V\) is the potential difference across the resistor and coil C, and \(p\) and \(q\) are constants.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 445, 688, 463]]<|/det|>
Plan a laboratory experiment to test the relationship between \(E\) and \(f\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 476, 625, 495]]<|/det|>
Draw a diagram showing the arrangement of your equipment.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 508, 698, 526]]<|/det|>
Explain how the results could be used to determine values for \(p\) and \(q\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 539, 384, 557]]<|/det|>
In your plan you should include:

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 570, 393, 588]]<|/det|>
· the procedure to be followed

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 600, 410, 617]]<|/det|>
· the measurements to be taken

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 630, 348, 647]]<|/det|>
· the control of variables

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 660, 351, 677]]<|/det|>
· the analysis of the data

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 688, 447, 705]]<|/det|>
· any safety precautions to be taken.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 97, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 771, 91]]<|/det|>
A block of modelling clay of mass \(M\) is attached to a string as shown in Fig. 2.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[235, 98, 759, 400]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 418, 532, 437]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 2.1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 450, 920, 484]]<|/det|>
A pellet travelling at speed \(u\) enters the block and causes the block to move through a vertical height \(h\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 495, 551, 514]]<|/det|>
The experiment is repeated for different values of \(M\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 526, 576, 545]]<|/det|>
It is suggested that \(h\) and \(M\) are related by the equation

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[432, 565, 566, 599]]<|/det|>
\[\frac{1}{h} = 2g\Big(\frac{M + Z}{uZ}\Big)^2\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 618, 594, 637]]<|/det|>
where \(g\) is the acceleration of free fall and \(Z\) is a constant.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 650, 146, 669]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 644, 680, 673]]<|/det|>
A graph is plotted of \(\sqrt{\frac{1}{h}}\) on the \(y\)-axis against \(M\) on the \(x\)-axis.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 680, 611, 699]]<|/det|>
Determine expressions for the gradient and \(y\)-intercept.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[500, 803, 917, 823]]<|/det|>
<form>gradient = ..........................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[475, 835, 917, 854]]<|/det|>
<form>y-intercept = ..........................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 852, 920, 870]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 146, 89]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 72, 494, 89]]<|/det|> Values of \(M\) and \(h\) are given in Table 2.1. <|ref|>table_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[457, 102, 539, 120]]<|/det|> Table 2.1 <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[212, 131, 784, 463]]<|/det|>
\(M/\mathrm {g}\)\(h/\mathrm {cm}\)\(\sqrt {\frac {1}{h}}/\mathrm {cm}^{-1/2}\)
56521.0 ± 0.2
63717.8 ± 0.2
67516.2 ± 0.2
72314.6 ± 0.2
79012.6 ± 0.2
89210.2 ± 0.2
<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 481, 609, 512]]<|/det|> Calculate and record values of \(\sqrt {\frac {1}{h}}/\mathrm {cm}^{- \frac {1}{2}}\) in Table 2.1. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 528, 507, 560]]<|/det|> Include the absolute uncertainties in \(\sqrt {\frac {1}{h}}.\) <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 535, 920, 554]]<|/det|> [2] <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 597, 143, 616]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 593, 180, 616]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 588, 524, 621]]<|/det|> Plot a graph of \(\sqrt {\frac {1}{h}}/\mathrm {cm}^{- \frac {1}{2}}\) against \(M/\mathrm {g}\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 636, 418, 670]]<|/det|> Include error bars for \(\sqrt {\frac {1}{h}}.\) <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 643, 920, 662]]<|/det|> [2] <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 691, 180, 708]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 688, 920, 723]]<|/det|> Draw the straight line of best fit and a worst acceptable straight line on your graph. Label both lines. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 707, 920, 726]]<|/det|> [2] <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 737, 181, 755]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 734, 920, 769]]<|/det|> Determine the gradient of the line of best fit. Include the absolute uncertainty in your answer. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[495, 920, 920, 938]]<|/det|>
gradient = ............................................................ [2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 72, 181, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>(iv)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 72, 920, 104]]<|/det|>
Determine the \(y\)-intercept of the line of best fit. Include the absolute uncertainty in your answer.

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[477, 210, 920, 228]]<|/det|>
\[y\mathrm{-intercept} = .................................................... [2]\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 241, 146, 260]]<|/det|>
<label>(d)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 241, 183, 260]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 241, 920, 275]]<|/det|>
Using your answers to (a), (c)(iii) and (c)(iv), determine the values of \(u\) and \(Z\). Include appropriate units.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 287, 366, 306]]<|/det|>
Data: \(g = 981 \text{cm s}^{-2}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[551, 443, 917, 460]]<|/det|>
<form>\(u = ............................................................\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[551, 473, 920, 491]]<|/det|>
<form>\(Z = ............................................................\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 490, 920, 508]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 520, 181, 539]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 520, 549, 539]]<|/det|>
Determine the percentage uncertainty in \(Z\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[339, 660, 920, 678]]<|/det|>
<form>percentage uncertainty in \(Z =\) ................................................. % [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 691, 146, 710]]<|/det|>
<label>(e)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 691, 861, 710]]<|/det|>
The experiment is repeated. Determine the mass \(M\) that gives a value of \(h\) of \(25.0 \text{cm}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[549, 845, 920, 863]]<|/det|>
<form>M = .................................................... g [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[833, 876, 920, 893]]<|/det|>
<mark>[Total: 15]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 903, 920, 939]]<|/det|>
